snippet: For novice investors in racehorses, buying into a syndicate with several horses is a good way to learn an unpredictable business without huge financial losses.
abstract: Paul Sullivan Wealth Matters column recommends that novice racehorse investors buy shares in a syndicate that owns several horses; notes that syndicates act like mutual funds, providing a good way to learn an unpredictable business without incurring major losses. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: I SPENT a day this week at Belmont Park, site of the final leg of the Triple Crown. I was with George Bolton, an investment adviser who once owned part of Curlin, winner of the 2007 Preakness Stakes and the current record holder for the most money won by a thoroughbred horse. On Wednesday, Orient Moon, his 3-year-old filly -- a young female horse -- was the favorite to win the third race. And for good reason. She was trained by Todd A. Pletcher, who has two horses in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, and was ridden by Johnny Velazquez, who won the Derby last year. But seconds after entering the gate, she got spooked, threw off Mr. Velazquez and was scratched from the race.

headline.main: Investing in a Racehorse Without Breaking the Bank
